newsitem.title: INDIA: India forex reserve rise may ease-SocGen Crosby.
newsitem.headline: India forex reserve rise may ease-SocGen Crosby.

text.p: The current pace of India's foreign exchange reserve accumulation cannot be sustained, SocGen Crosby Research said on Thursday.
"In 1996/97 the forex reserves rose very rapidly from $15.8 billion in February 1996 to $22.5 billion in April 1997," SocGen Crosby said in its May South Asia Quarterly Economic Review.
This was made possible by several factors such as Reserve Bank of India's tightening of export credit in February 1996 following "misuse of the subsidised credit facility", it said.
"This forced many exporters to repatriate export earnings from earlier years during 1996/97 (April-March)," it said.

"However, the present pace of forex reserve accumulation cannot be sustained especially given the slow export growth and the prospect of rising imports on the back of an industrial revival," the report said.
"As the net injection of foreign liquidity tapers off, the Indian financial system will witness a mild tightening in liquidity in the fourth quarter of 1997/98," it said.
